Q14: My most memorable experience with wildlife isn't necessarily positive. I was camping near Gena, Louisiana with a few friends because one of them invited me and a few others to go along with him while he dealt with the death of a family member. The camping was great, but during the early morning hours while I was making breakfast I picked up something and didn't notice that there was a snake on it. The snake lunged and bit me in the chest, which had me freaking out for a little bit. Everyone panicked and a couple of friends wanted to try sucking out the venom while driving me to the nearest hospital. Thankfully I noticed it didn't seem to strike me with fangs so after capturing it and upon looking it up we found it was just a rat snake. Q14: Last spring a bird started building her nest in my garage. It was very hot outside and slightly cooler in the garage so I let her keep building. I kept an eye on the nest and once the eggs were laid and the babies hatched, I would watch them for several minutes every day. When they were big enough they started to fall out of their nest onto the concrete floor. Their mother was trying to get them to follow her outside. I picked them up and brought them out to the grass so they wouldn't hurt themselves. They hung out in the front yard for a few days until they were able to fly away. It was a very sweet, precious experience.

For whatever reason, I was looking at the right time to see the dog snapping at a duckling and actually catching it. I was right next to the door to the back deck, so I dashed out and started barking at the dog. It was startled enough that it dropped the duckling and looked around. That duckling hauled duckbutt down to the lake and hurried to catch up with his family. They swam across the lake to our yard and I could swear the mama duck was looking at me appreciatively.

Q20: I had a very bad interaction with bats. I was working for a traveling puppet show, and we had an outdoor evening show right next a barn. We were told that when we left, we had to go in the barn and turn off the outside lights (which is something that should have been done by the people who hired us). It was getting dark as the show ended, and as we were taking down the stage there were bats swarming around us. I realize now that there were probably insects all around us, and the bats were going after those, but to us it was like the bats were dive-bombing us. We freaked out (me and my boss), and decided to leave the rest of the stage and come back for it in the morning. When we went into the barn we discovered that that was where the bats lived, and there were hundreds of them in there. We didn't turn the lights off, we just hurried to our van and left. I like bats now, but that experience really freaked my out.
Q23: I am concerned that over the last 15 years since I moved into my house, bats have become a rare sight in the summer evenings. I used to see several any evening I went out at dusk, but now I hardly ever see one.

I kinda played with the bird that way, get close, go far, like a game of tag. The next night, I found the humming bird sleeping soundly on my plant! Q12: I seek out places where I might see wildlife (e.g. outdoor parks, nature areas)
Q43: If you're an animal lover, volunteering your time at a wildlife sanctuary offers the chance to surround yourself with creatures you love while doing some good at the same time. And for those looking for a volunteering destination, the African continent with its iconic wildlife is an obvious pick. But before you book that flight, there are a few things to consider. Not all wildlife sanctuaries were created equal, and there are important questions you should ask to ensure you'll be devoting your time to a sanctuary or project with solid credentials, and one that has animal welfare and conservation at its heart. Q14: When I traveled to Peru, I had a pretty awesome experience with a llama in Machu Picchu. The cutie was relaxing on one of the terraces and I was able to go right up to him and pet him. Q15: bat, winged mammal of the order Chiroptera, which includes 900–1,000 species classified in about 200 genera and 17 families. Bats range in size from a wingspread of over 5 ft (150 cm) to a wingspread of less than 2 in. (5 cm). They are found in nearly all parts of the world but are most numerous in the tropics; there are about 39 species in the United States. Most bats are economically valuable because of the large number of insects they consume.
Q16: ets face it, bats get a pretty bad rep. Many times in the media they are portrayed as scary, blood sucking, rabid creatures. The vast majority of bats will never get rabies. And quite a few species can be pretty darn cute! As someone who has spent time studying bats in the wild, I jumped at the opportunity to share what I’ve learned with others—it’s something I believe all biologists should do. Here are my reasons for liking bats (and why you should like them too!).
Q20: Australian bat lyssavirus (ABLV) infects a number of flying fox and insectivorous bats species in Australia. Human infection with ABLV is inevitably fatal unless prior vaccination and/or post-exposure treatment (PET) is given. Despite ongoing public health messaging about the risks associated with bat contact, surveillance data have revealed a four-fold increase in the number of people receiving PET for bat exposure in NSW between 2007 and 2011. Our study aimed to better understand these human – bat interactions in order to identify additional risk communication messages that could lower the risk of potential ABLV exposure. All people aged 18 years or over whom received PET for non-occupation related potential ABLV exposure in the Hunter New England Local Health District of Australia between July 2011 and July 2013 were considered eligible for the study. Eligible participants were invited to a telephone interview to explore the circumstances of their bat contact. Interviews were then transcribed and thematically analysed by two independent investigators.

If you come around early to mid-December, you can witness baby Adélies because they are usually born around that time.

Q15: Most bats are nocturnal predators and just thinking about these mysterious creatures gives most people an uneasy feeling (unless you are a bat lover). Bats may be considered mysterious and unpredictable. When you are interpreting this dream, look carefully at the details and your emotional reactions to the events in the dream. This dream may be related to discrete or covert behaviors. Your unconscious mind may be relating feelings to you in regard to behaviors that you or someone else prefers to keep a secret.
Q16: Bats aren’t blind and can use their eyes. However, many species use echolocation to find their prey and “see” their surroundings. They make calls that will travel through the air until it hits an object. This call then bounces off the object and echos back to the bat, letting them know where the object is (so its unlikely that they’ll fly in your hair). Bats can make up to 160 calls per SECOND as they close in on their prey. This would seem like a noisy way to get food, but most bat calls are at ultrasound frequencies that are too high for us (and their prey) to hear.
Q49: The body of the smallest bat found in the UK, the pipistrelle, measures only about 4cm long and weighs around 5 grams - that's less than a £1 coin! In comparison the UK's largest bat, the noctule, is almost twice the size and weighs up to 40 grams.

Q14:
my husband and I went to Vegas, and we chose to go to some of the places away from the strip. There are a lot of outdoor things to do around the outskirts of Vegas. We went to "Valley of Fire" because we love the rocks there and the Indian Petroglyphs on the rocks. We often go in the afternoon so that we can spend some time in the dark there too because of just how many rocks we can see.  

One night, we took a wrong turn and had to back up to turn around. When we did, we were suddenly faced with a Bobcat just about 5 feet in front of the car. We were safe inside the car, so that was not a problem. He/she just stood there staring at us, and we stared back in awe. I grew up in a state where bobcats are common, yet I'd never seen one up close before. 

I was sad to see it run off after about 2 minutes. It was AMAZING.
Q15:
Cute, furry, tiny and beneficial. I live in a city where one of the largest bat colonies in the US live. In fact, most of them (about 1 million) live underneath the bridge just up the road from my house. Every night, at sundown, they wake up, come out from under the bridge to go out to feed. There are so many they look like black ribbons floating across the sky here at sunset.

When I sit outside my home at night, I can hear them chirping as they fly over.
Q16: As a child, I was petrified of them thanks to Dracula. I did not live in a city where I ever saw them so that part of it.
Q20: As explained on previous page, we can go to the Congress Avenue bridge in my city to see them any night during the summer. I've gone at time to watch them come out. look for youtube videos about it. You can stand right on the bridge to watch. I did so, but it was loud because of so many people. I prefer to sit outside in my own yard at sundown and just listen to them and watch them on my own at night. They are comforting.
Q23:
I used to be a bit scared of the really large bats with the large membrane wings, though we dont have those here in my city. We have tiny, Mexican Free Tail Bats. However! There's an awesome page on Facebook for a bat rescue in Australia and they rescue the really big bats that I used to be scared of. They have taught me that they are so sweet, docile and only eat fruit. And they are so CUTE closet up. I am less freaked about by their big membrane wings now. 

Here's the page..the videos are AWESOME: https://www.facebook.com/batzillathebat/?ref=br_rs

Q14: When I was a child my dad and I found a raccoon that was left alone. We knew this because we found it's mother dead on the side of the road. I don't know why he thought this, but I remember my dad saying it died from some sort of sickness. As we were looking at it and talking about we heard the baby raccoon in a tree. It was tucked in a little hole at the crotch of the tree. My dad pulled the baby coon out and we took it home. We ended up raising the raccoon and he lived with us for about 5 years. My dad was friends with the local small town vet and he would make house visits to check up on the coon the entire time we had him. This experience brought me closer to nature. I had a new found respect for wildlife and Mother Earth.

I was afraid to open the tent fly and draw attention to myself, and after 45 minutes or so the sounds became fainter as the animal wandered away.  In the morning  I searched but could find no sign of the visitor.  When I got back from the trip I searched YouTube and found a video of a cougar "screaming" - same sound!

Q45_4_TEXT: They're either used as a scare tactic in a tense movie, like a big group swooping out from a cave or dark area. Bats aren't normally aggressors like hurting people. And sometimes they're portrayed nice and sweet like in Fern Gully.

Q23: I just think there's nothing wrong with bats. Like any other creature, just do your best to keep to yourself and they should leave you alone. Like bees or anything else. Q14: One night there was a baby skunk in our yard.  He was a cute little thing, but we weren't sure if he was old enough to spray or not.  We didn't want him to take up permanent residence there, and we didn't want our cats to get sprayed, so we had to figure out how to relocate him.  We called around trying to find a trap, but no one had one.  So we figured out how to catch him in a plastic container, and we drove him to the state park and set him free by the river.  Before we let him out, we put a little pile of cat food on the ground to keep him busy.  We thought he would be scared, but he wasn't at all!  We tipped the container, and he just strolled out like he owned the place.  He went right to the cat food and ate all of it, and wandered off into the trees.  When we went back to get our container later, we found little wet skunk footprints along the trail.
Q16: I always loved watching bats.  We used to watch around the streetlights, because they would go there to catch the insects that were attracted to the light.  I never had any bad experiences with them being inside or anything like that, so they were just something cool to watch at night.
Q20:
We found a bat clinging to the outside of an air conditioner once.  It was during the day, and it was just hanging upside down, clinging to the grill on the air conditioning unit.  We were trying to figure out if we should do anything with it, but we left it alone for a few minutes, and when we came back, it was gone. 
My coolest interaction with bats was in Guatemala City.  We were parked close to the LDS temple in Vista Hermosa, which is really well lit outside at night.  I was just looking at the lights, and I realized there were hundreds of bats swarming around above the temple.  I have never seen so many bats in one place before or since.
